data: 1 00:00:07,420 --> 00:00:10,499 Hello, this is Danny Boyle, the director of 28 Days Later. 2 00:00:10,500 --> 00:00:13,202 I'm Alex Garland, writer. 3 00:00:16,820 --> 00:00:20,339 (Danny) I don't know whether Fox ever noticed this, 4 00:00:20,340 --> 00:00:23,099 but we shifted the timing of the music 5 00:00:23,100 --> 00:00:28,124 on this opening credit sequence on their logo. 6 00:00:32,140 --> 00:00:35,730 (Alex) This is stuff we mocked up. 7 00:00:37,300 --> 00:00:40,699 (Danny) When we first started this, 8 00:00:40,700 --> 00:00:44,259 Alex wrote all these images for the beginning, 9 00:00:44,260 --> 00:00:49,059 a lot of which were based on Sorious Samura's footage from Sierra Leone. 10 00:00:49,060 --> 00:00:52,859 We debated at one point about using real footage 11 00:00:52,860 --> 00:00:57,379 of terrible civil unrest and death and violence. 12 00:00:57,380 --> 00:01:02,939 We decided, rightly, I think, that we wouldn't use anything that involved any real deaths. 13 00:01:02,940 --> 00:01:08,499 The footage that is in there that does involve deaths, like the necklace thing, 14 00:01:08,500 --> 00:01:11,099 it was all mocked up. 15 00:01:11,100 --> 00:01:15,099 - (Alex) In London. - (Danny) On a very nice day in Docklands. 16 00:01:15,100 --> 00:01:18,019 We tried to make it look like real footage from the past. 17 00:01:18,020 --> 00:01:21,219 We shot the film on DV and the news footage at the beginning 18 00:01:21,220 --> 00:01:26,050 helps you into the slight different quality of the visuals. 19 00:01:27,740 --> 00:01:32,459 This is Johnny, who's a chimp from Stuttgart 20 00:01:32,460 --> 00:01:35,979 which is where we had to go to film this sequence. 21 00:01:35,980 --> 00:01:39,939 There are only two working troupes of chimps for use in the film industry. 22 00:01:39,940 --> 00:01:42,499 One's in Los Angeles and one's in Stuttgart. 23 00:01:42,500 --> 00:01:45,739 It's a kind of family circus. Amazing people. 24 00:01:45,740 --> 00:01:51,002 They were very kind to us when we shot there over three or four days. 25 00:01:55,740 --> 00:01:59,019 We did debate having different nationalities. 26 00:01:59,020 --> 00:02:01,539 For instance, we were gonna make them German. 27 00:02:01,540 --> 00:02:05,899 At one point we were gonna make them Scandinavian. Then Japanese. 28 00:02:05,900 --> 00:02:09,219 Even at point, we thought of making them American. 29 00:02:09,220 --> 00:02:14,847 (Alex) But the quarantine idea eventually locked them down to the UK. 30 00:02:16,860 --> 00:02:22,579 This was really where we were gonna try and get as much exposition as we needed 31 00:02:22,580 --> 00:02:26,250 out of the way in this opening sequence. 32 00:02:28,140 --> 00:02:31,339 I suppose we've got a little bit dropped in later, 33 00:02:31,340 --> 00:02:37,659 but we had this idea which was to set the premise up as quickly as possible, 34 00:02:37,660 --> 00:02:41,045 And then return to it as little as possible. 35 00:02:42,140 --> 00:02:44,779 (Danny) It looks very distressing for the chimps, 36 00:02:44,780 --> 00:02:50,008 the cages that they're in and the bed that he's lying on. 37 00:02:52,220 --> 00:02:56,739 But we were guided completely, 38 00:02:56,740 --> 00:02:59,979 and took in what we were allowed to do and the sizes of the cages, 39 00:02:59,980 --> 00:03:03,579 by the guy who looks after the chimps. 40 00:03:03,580 --> 00:03:09,684 He breeds them. He brings them up from birth and keeps them until they're in their 405. 41 00:03:10,340 --> 00:03:14,259 Interestingly, one reason there are so few working chimps any more 42 00:03:14,260 --> 00:03:19,779 is that because of recent legislation, they're not allowed to put down chimps any more. 43 00:03:19,780 --> 00:03:23,139 You can only work them until they're seven or eight years old 44 00:03:23,140 --> 00:03:25,219 and they live to about 40 or 50. 45 00:03:25,220 --> 00:03:29,419 But for the last 20 or 30 years of their life they're very difficult to work with. 46 00:03:29,420 --> 00:03:34,842 This man works with them right through. And they adore him. They were wonderful. 47 00:03:37,140 --> 00:03:41,447 This is the setup, as Alex was talking about. 48 00:03:41,940 --> 00:03:46,779 When I first read this scene, I thought what a wonderful premise it was for a film, 49 00:03:46,780 --> 00:03:49,859 this idea of a psychological virus. 50 00:03:49,860 --> 00:03:53,339 We've all seen movies with viruses escaping, 51 00:03:53,340 --> 00:03:56,699 but they're usually some kind of biological or chemical agent. 52 00:03:56,700 --> 00:04:01,979 But the idea - which is fantasy, which is a slight sci-fi premise - of a psychological virus 53 00:04:01,980 --> 00:04:08,210 I just think is a brilliant original idea and a fantastic premise to start the film on. 54 00:04:18,460 --> 00:04:20,939 (Alex) This sequence is interesting for me 55 00:04:20,940 --> 00:04:28,859 because I think this scene more than any other is pure genre in the way that it's written. 56 00:04:28,860 --> 00:04:33,179 But in the way that it's shot and the way that Danny executed it, 57 00:04:33,180 --> 00:04:36,486 it pulls it away from that. 58 00:04:38,660 --> 00:04:42,059 It was quite strange for me watching this for the first time 59 00:04:42,060 --> 00:04:48,419 because I had to get used to that different approach. 60 00:04:48,420 --> 00:04:52,859 With the rest of the film, it was supposed to be moving away from genre, 61 00:04:52,860 --> 00:04:57,979 but this felt almost like a set piece. 62 00:04:57,980 --> 00:05:01,684 But the execution of it, I think, is terrific. 63 00:05:12,300 --> 00:05:15,401 (Danny) It's always useful to remember the very first time you read a script. 64 00:05:16,340 --> 00:05:21,299 That's the last time you're as close in experience to the audience's, seeing it fresh. 65 00:05:21,300 --> 00:05:25,139 This was the thing that stuck in my mind, the use of the title - as a subtitle. 66 00:05:25,140 --> 00:05:28,419 There was no title. I thought that was brilliant. I love that. 67 00:05:28,420 --> 00:05:32,059 So we were determined not to have any names up front. 68 00:05:32,060 --> 00:05:34,219 (Alex) That's our Tootsie cut. 69 00:05:34,220 --> 00:05:36,059 (laughter) 70 00:05:36,060 --> 00:05:38,979 In Tootsie Dustin Hoffman realises, 71 00:05:38,980 --> 00:05:41,979 in order to make it as an actor, he has to dress as a woman. 72 00:05:41,980 --> 00:05:46,059 Then you just cut to him walking down the street as a woman. 73 00:05:46,060 --> 00:05:50,059 You never show him dressing up. I think they show that later. 74 00:05:50,060 --> 00:05:53,969 That's what we did here. We tried to cut to the chase. 75 00:05:55,340 --> 00:05:59,139 (Danny) But we put him in green pyjamas instead. 76 00:05:59,140 --> 00:06:02,047 (Alex) Or no pyjamas. 77 00:06:02,860 --> 00:06:07,406 (Danny) There are two types of hospitals in Britain. 78 00:06:08,500 --> 00:06:10,579 There's the more Victorian type. 79 00:06:10,580 --> 00:06:14,659 Then there's the modern type, usually associated with private healthcare. 80 00:06:14,660 --> 00:06:17,739 But this is a National Health hospital in Acton. 81 00:06:17,740 --> 00:06:22,659 It's a day hospital, for day operations. It had a wonderful modern quality about it. 82 00:06:22,660 --> 00:06:29,419 We always try to emphasise the modern in British life. 83 00:06:29,420 --> 00:06:33,819 It's just a choice, rather than looking backwards. 84 00:06:33,820 --> 00:06:39,179 It has a feeling about it almost of a hotel, somehow, a modern hotel, 85 00:06:39,180 --> 00:06:42,979 especially in the wider shots coming up. 86 00:06:42,980 --> 00:06:46,019 Cillian was very worried about doing these scenes naked. 87 00:06:46,020 --> 00:06:48,779 We had the usual closed set. 88 00:06:48,780 --> 00:06:54,691 Nobody was allowed to make any jokes all day in case they were misinterpreted. 89 00:07:05,060 --> 00:07:09,699 We made a big choice about whether there were gonna be bodies. 90 00:07:09,700 --> 00:07:13,339 Indeed we did shoot some bodies in this opening sequence, 91 00:07:13,340 --> 00:07:18,019 but we decided to follow one of our instincts which was that, 92 00:07:18,020 --> 00:07:20,979 rather than trying to litter the world with corpses, 93 00:07:20,980 --> 00:07:23,979 we were better to make it almost symbolic. 94 00:07:23,980 --> 00:07:28,499 The emptiness of the place stood for something that had gone wrong 95 00:07:28,500 --> 00:07:34,001 rather than specific reality of corpses lying around and blood everywhere. 96 00:07:35,380 --> 00:07:40,179 (Alex) Atmosphere and surrealism over plot requirements. 97 00:07:40,180 --> 00:07:44,771 It's like an aesthetic decision. 98 00:07:45,500 --> 00:07:51,179 But it's something we've been picked up on. "Why aren't there more bodies around?" 99 00:07:51,180 --> 00:07:55,099 There's not really a good logical reason for it in storytelling terms, 100 00:07:55,100 --> 00:07:58,739 it's just because it feels more interesting. 101 00:07:58,740 --> 00:08:02,444 Hopefully, that's a legitimate reason. 102 00:08:09,660 --> 00:08:16,139 (Danny) My life, since I've become involved in making films, 103 00:08:16,140 --> 00:08:18,659 has centred around two questions so far. 104 00:08:18,660 --> 00:08:22,979 One was "How did you get Ewan McGregor to come out of the toilet in Trainspotting?" 105 00:08:22,980 --> 00:08:26,699 The second was "What was it like to work with Leonardo DiCaprio?" 106 00:08:26,700 --> 00:08:29,659 I'm grateful that both of them have been replaced by 107 00:08:29,660 --> 00:08:33,699 "How did you shoot the London scenes on this one?" 108 00:08:33,700 --> 00:08:37,059 The answer is in the most obvious way you'd expect. 109 00:08:37,060 --> 00:08:41,499 We managed somehow to close the streets down, albeit only for brief moments of time. 110 00:08:41,500 --> 00:08:44,819 We used multicameras - the digital cameras. 111 00:08:44,820 --> 00:08:47,739 We filmed for maybe 90 seconds or two minutes 112 00:08:47,740 --> 00:08:51,979 where the traffic was held back by these wonderful traffic marshals that we used, 113 00:08:51,980 --> 00:08:54,419 who were students and friends. 114 00:08:54,420 --> 00:08:56,499 My daughter Grace was one of them. 115 00:08:56,500 --> 00:09:00,299 Holding back the traffic at different times. 116 00:09:00,300 --> 00:09:06,099 And we managed to get this footage that is a great advert for the film. 117 00:09:06,100 --> 00:09:13,139 It's one of things that's helped us sell the premise of the film enthrallingly, I hope. 118 00:09:13,140 --> 00:09:18,419 (Alex) I think, somewhere around here, there's one of our deliberate mistakes. 119 00:09:18,420 --> 00:09:22,059 I've always imagined that there's a car moving in the background. 120 00:09:22,060 --> 00:09:25,939 It's not here. Where is it? It's along the Embankment. 121 00:09:25,940 --> 00:09:30,499 - (Danny) Alex is convinced there's a car. - (Alex) It was while you were talking. 122 00:09:30,500 --> 00:09:33,659 We think he's just trying to undermine the film. (laughs) 123 00:09:33,660 --> 00:09:35,619 (coughing) 124 00:09:35,620 --> 00:09:40,099 - I've got a terrible cold. Sorry about that. - (Alex) He's had a big weekend. 125 00:09:40,100 --> 00:09:43,739 You wouldn't be allowed to do this. We did this before September 11th. 126 00:09:43,740 --> 00:09:45,819 To put a bus on its side in Whitehall, 127 00:09:45,820 --> 00:09:49,339 outside Downing Street where the prime minister's residence is, 128 00:09:49,340 --> 00:09:51,419 you wouldn't be allowed to now. 129 00:09:51,420 --> 00:09:56,259 We only just got away with it, helped by the inventiveness of Mark Tildesley, the designer, 130 00:09:56,260 --> 00:10:00,099 who swore blind to them that he could get it in and out of there in 15 minutes. 131 00:10:00,100 --> 00:10:04,659 And he proved himself right. I think they were surprised that we kept to our word. 132 00:10:04,660 --> 00:10:07,819 We said to these places "We'll go in and we'll shoot 133 00:10:07,820 --> 00:10:11,179 and we'll be out of there by 7.30 or 8 o'clock in the morning." 134 00:10:11,180 --> 00:10:14,219 They're used to the bullshit that film people are full of, 135 00:10:14,220 --> 00:10:16,859 where they end up taking 18 hours to shoot it. 136 00:10:16,860 --> 00:10:19,259 But each day we kept to our word. 137 00:10:19,260 --> 00:10:23,219 This stuff is based on a photograph out of Cambodia, 138 00:10:23,220 --> 00:10:26,924 after Pol Pot was driven out of Phnom Penh. 139 00:10:29,060 --> 00:10:32,979 There was money all in the streets because it was useless. 140 00:10:32,980 --> 00:10:38,179 There's various references like that that we had, 141 00:10:38,180 --> 00:10:44,059 which just gave us a visual image to add to details of the story 142 00:10:44,060 --> 00:10:47,570 as he makes his way through the city. 143 00:11:24,780 --> 00:11:27,699 This is a very busy part of London - Tottenham Court Road. 144 00:11:27,700 --> 00:11:32,849 And Centre Point, the famous empty building. Or partially empty now. 145 00:11:34,500 --> 00:11:38,419 We didn't use music at first in this sequence 146 00:11:38,420 --> 00:11:43,379 and that moment, with the alarm going off, used to give you a heart attack 147 00:11:43,380 --> 00:11:45,859 if you didn't have some background music. 148 00:11:45,860 --> 00:11:48,619 We used this track from Godspeed You! Black Emperor, 149 00:11:48,620 --> 00:11:52,059 French Canadian anarchists who allowed us to use their music, 150 00:11:52,060 --> 00:11:54,619 this driving, apocalyptic, climactic music 151 00:11:54,620 --> 00:11:57,779 which I think is a wonderful addition to the film. 152 00:11:57,780 --> 00:12:02,099 (Alex) This is this image that became... 153 00:12:02,100 --> 00:12:06,259 Prescient is not the right word because it's after the fact, 154 00:12:06,260 --> 00:12:09,579 but this was shot pre-September 11th. 155 00:12:09,580 --> 00:12:11,979 What was it from? Was it Peking? 156 00:12:11,980 --> 00:12:14,579 (Danny) It was an earthquake in China years ago, 157 00:12:14,580 --> 00:12:17,739 where they'd done the same thing of trying to contact each other 158 00:12:17,740 --> 00:12:21,444 when normal communication breaks down. 159 00:12:23,780 --> 00:12:29,139 But we came up with the idea because there were billboards around Eros, 160 00:12:29,140 --> 00:12:31,219 the statue in Piccadilly Circus. 161 00:12:31,220 --> 00:12:33,299 We thought "How can we use that?" 162 00:12:33,300 --> 00:12:38,019 If you're flowing, something good comes out of things. 163 00:12:38,020 --> 00:12:40,882 Good ides come out of problems. 164 00:12:45,700 --> 00:12:52,339 I have to thank the girl who spent three months writing up all those notices. 165 00:12:52,340 --> 00:12:54,699 We did a lot of filming in East London. 166 00:12:54,700 --> 00:13:00,339 This is a church in... not in Spitalfields, in Limehouse in East London. 167 00:13:00,340 --> 00:13:03,499 It's one of the famous Hawksmoor churches. 168 00:13:03,500 --> 00:13:08,139 There are seven of them, which are supposedly in the shape of a pentangle. 169 00:13:08,140 --> 00:13:09,779 (Alex) Something like that. 170 00:13:09,780 --> 00:13:12,939 (Danny) Some Satanic thing. Don't know whether it's true. 171 00:13:12,940 --> 00:13:19,647 (Alex) If you read From Hell by Alan Moore, he goes into a lot of detail about those churches. 172 00:13:20,300 --> 00:13:25,939 (Danny) This was fun, telling the church warden what we were gonna write on his wall. 173 00:13:25,940 --> 00:13:28,419 But we were honest and he gave us permission. 174 00:13:28,420 --> 00:13:33,011 You can just about read it, which is how we wanted it to look. 175 00:13:33,380 --> 00:13:36,659 What we were saying earlier about the bodies in the street, 176 00:13:36,660 --> 00:13:38,899 when you decide on that and clear them out, 177 00:13:38,900 --> 00:13:44,819 we came up with this idea that we'd put all the bodies in a church. 178 00:13:44,820 --> 00:13:48,019 That was sort of influenced by stories that we'd heard 179 00:13:48,020 --> 00:13:53,979 about Rwanda and places like that, with corpses ending up in churches. 180 00:13:53,980 --> 00:13:57,099 We thought it'd just be a dumping house for corpses, 181 00:13:57,100 --> 00:14:02,249 some kind of mortuary or makeshift cemetery for the corpses. 182 00:14:03,020 --> 00:14:08,859 It felt like the film was evolving then, out of the circumstances, 183 00:14:08,860 --> 00:14:13,339 and that he was understanding as he went along in the way that we are. 184 00:14:13,340 --> 00:14:17,442 He knows nothing like we know virtually nothing. 185 00:14:40,660 --> 00:14:45,459 All those corpses that you see in the church are actually volunteers who turned up for us. 186 00:14:45,460 --> 00:14:48,099 I think we gave them a free cup of tea or something. 187 00:14:48,100 --> 00:14:51,819 A generous offering for them to come for a few hours. They were students. 188 00:14:51,820 --> 00:14:56,539 We couldn't afford to hire extras in the conventional way. We didn't have the money. 189 00:14:56,540 --> 00:14:59,139 They were people who just turned up and helped us. 190 00:14:59,140 --> 00:15:01,739 The man who played the priest was an enormous help. 191 00:15:01,740 --> 00:15:04,579 He did lots of workshops with us about movement. 192 00:15:04,580 --> 00:15:08,363 He's a brilliant movement artist. 193 00:15:08,700 --> 00:15:13,007 I did all these different states, showing the actors... 194 00:15:13,100 --> 00:15:16,339 I haven't got time to go into it here, but he was an enormous help 195 00:15:16,340 --> 00:15:21,139 in developing the physical movement of the Infected, which he starts off there - 196 00:15:21,140 --> 00:15:27,099 and is an erratic, frenetic, violent, impatient gesture, 197 00:15:27,100 --> 00:15:30,007 a bit like the feeling of rage, really. 198 00:15:31,300 --> 00:15:37,370 (Alex) This was the day everyone wanted to be on set, to see this petrol station blow up. 199 00:15:39,700 --> 00:15:43,659 200 grand. It was the most expensive single thing we did, wasn't it? 200 00:15:43,660 --> 00:15:48,059 (Danny) Apart from your fee, Alex, yeah. No, I'm only kidding. 201 00:15:48,060 --> 00:15:51,859 (Alex) Was I earning over 200 grand? I'll have to bring that up. 202 00:15:51,860 --> 00:15:55,379 (Danny) Actually, I think it cost L250,000 in total. 203 00:15:55,380 --> 00:15:59,339 It seems like, and is, an enormous amount of money, obviously. 204 00:15:59,340 --> 00:16:03,819 But what we always feel is that when you put the film out to be for a mainstream audience, 205 00:16:03,820 --> 00:16:09,699 they're not gonna say "It's a British film, we don't mind if the explosions aren't good." 206 00:16:09,700 --> 00:16:13,019 They want it to be as good as a Mel Gibson film, 207 00:16:13,020 --> 00:16:18,219 as whatever's out there, that you're competing with in the multiplex. 208 00:16:18,220 --> 00:16:21,619 So I think it's money well spent and it's the end of our first reel, 209 00:16:21,620 --> 00:16:25,299 so there's an extraordinary sequence which starts with London empty 210 00:16:25,300 --> 00:16:28,659 and builds to this incredible explosion across it. 211 00:16:28,660 --> 00:16:32,739 We used many cameras. It's brilliantly cut by our editor, Chris Gill, 212 00:16:32,740 --> 00:16:38,059 who did some wonderful cutting on the film to make the best of our limited resources. 213 00:16:38,060 --> 00:16:41,499 That's based on a famous photograph from Northern Ireland 214 00:16:41,500 --> 00:16:43,579 of people escaping from a bomb blast 215 00:16:43,580 --> 00:16:49,411 by just happening to be in the gaps between windows as the bomb goes off inside. 216 00:16:51,660 --> 00:16:55,939 This is Canary Wharf tube station on the Docklands Light Railway 217 00:16:55,940 --> 00:16:59,139 which is a modern piece of infrastructure in London. 218 00:16:59,140 --> 00:17:04,139 The idea of this - although we partly built some of this in the studio - 219 00:17:04,140 --> 00:17:08,859 was that it was a shop in a tube station where they hide, 220 00:17:08,860 --> 00:17:14,179 where they live for a bit, these two other survivors that he's meeting. 221 00:17:14,180 --> 00:17:18,299 (Alex) It was a weirdly difficult scene, this one. 222 00:17:18,300 --> 00:17:24,325 I never felt that, from my end, I cracked it really. 223 00:17:24,900 --> 00:17:31,459 It was a tricky one because, like the opening scene, it required exposition. 224 00:17:31,460 --> 00:17:36,419 Fitting exposition into conversation and dialogue is a nightmare. 225 00:17:36,420 --> 00:17:40,647 It's an art and I was really struggling here. 226 00:17:40,980 --> 00:17:47,939 Danny did a shot from Jim over to Selena, which is coming up quite soon, 227 00:17:47,940 --> 00:17:52,419 that allowed for us to play around a bit in ADR, 228 00:17:52,420 --> 00:17:55,964 to mess around with what was being said. 229 00:17:56,580 --> 00:17:58,659 It never felt quite right to me. 230 00:17:58,660 --> 00:18:01,419 In fact, we shot this scene twice, didn't we? 231 00:18:01,420 --> 00:18:05,099 (Danny) Yeah, we reshot a whole section of it. 232 00:18:05,100 --> 00:18:11,339 We rebuilt half the shot in the studio later and reshot a section of it, 233 00:18:11,340 --> 00:18:15,819 to take account of a slightly different exposition. 234 00:18:15,820 --> 00:18:17,899 (Alex) I think a couple of lines work. 235 00:18:17,900 --> 00:18:23,939 One is when Jim starts asking where people's parents are, and they say "They're dead." 236 00:18:23,940 --> 00:18:30,459 If you can convey information as simply as that, that's the best way to do it. 237 00:18:30,460 --> 00:18:37,122 It gets a lot across very quickly. The audience fills in all the gaps around that quite quickly. 238 00:18:38,260 --> 00:18:41,139 I think it's something to do with confidence, 239 00:18:41,140 --> 00:18:44,939 knowing how much and how little you can put in. 240 00:18:44,940 --> 00:18:47,739 What do you call this? It's not a tracking shot. 241 00:18:47,740 --> 00:18:48,819 (laughter) 242 00:18:48,820 --> 00:18:52,139 - You left me space to piss around in. - (Danny) It's a pan. 243 00:18:52,140 --> 00:18:57,164 - It's an interminable pan. - (Alex) I'm gonna call it a tracking shot. 244 00:18:57,900 --> 00:19:03,659 (Danny) I love the idea of them living off Maltesers and Coke 245 00:19:03,660 --> 00:19:08,739 and junk food that would remain, that has an endless best-by date. 246 00:19:08,740 --> 00:19:13,139 So they end up living off that kind of stuff rather than fresh food. 247 00:19:13,140 --> 00:19:16,844 I thought it was a great image. I loved that. 248 00:19:20,420 --> 00:19:24,739 There was a different joke at the beginning of it, when the guy with the mask came in. 249 00:19:24,740 --> 00:19:28,339 Wasn't it Luke said to Darth Vader "I know what you got for Christmas"? 250 00:19:28,340 --> 00:19:31,139 He said "Why?"
